title: 112_s1942
content: The Act may be cited as the "Senior Transportation and Mobility Improvement Act of 2011". Congress acknowledges the increasing number of individuals aged 65 and older in the United States, with a projected increase from 40,000,000 in 2010 to 72,000,000 in 2030. Reports highlight the challenges faced by seniors in accessing transportation options, with a significant portion of them unable to drive. According to a 2004 report, older non-drivers in the US make significantly fewer trips for various activities compared to older drivers. In 2009, the program under section 5310 of title 49 provided over 43,000,000 rides to older adults and people with disabilities, highlighting the importance of access to mobility management services for transit. Access to mobility management services is crucial for transit and human services systems to meet the needs of older adults and people with disabilities. This person-centered strategy helps individuals and families choose the best transportation options based on their circumstances, preferences, and mobility needs. Public transportation services for elderly individuals and individuals with disabilities are addressed in Section 3. Section 5310 of title 49, United States Code, is amended to allow states to use excess funds for operating costs related to vehicles and capital assets acquired using funds under this section, including insurance, fuel, and driver compensation. The Federal share of these costs is also specified. The amendment to Section 5310 of title 49, United States Code allows states to use excess funds for operating costs related to vehicles and capital assets acquired using funds under this section. Recipients of funding must submit an annual report detailing coordination of activities with grants under the Older Americans Act. The Federal share of costs is also specified. The United States Code is amended to include exceptions for certain states and mobility management grants for capital projects. Additionally, the National Transit Database is amended to include section 5307, 5310, or 5311 for funding eligibility. The National Transit Database is amended to include data on activities funded by grants under sections 5310 and 5311, detailing the number of vehicles purchased and rides provided by each recipient and state. SEC. 4. METROPOLITAN AND STATEWIDE TRANSPORTATION PLANNING. Metropolitan Transportation Planning section 5303(i) of title 49, United States Code, amended to include participation by older individuals and people with disabilities in developing transportation plans. Definitions of disability and older individual align with the Older Americans Act of 1965. Organizations representing these groups must be included in the planning process. The amended Metropolitan Transportation Planning section 5303(i) of title 49, United States Code now includes participation by older individuals and people with disabilities in developing transportation plans. Organizations representing these groups must have a reasonable opportunity to comment on the transportation plan, and their input must be considered in the development of the plan. The amended Statewide Transportation Planning section now requires participation by older individuals and people with disabilities in reviewing and commenting on transportation plans before they become final. The Statewide Transportation Planning section now mandates the involvement of organizations representing older individuals and individuals with disabilities in providing comments on and reviewing transportation plans. The Statewide Transportation Planning section now requires organizations representing older individuals and individuals with disabilities to review and comment on transportation plans before they are finalized. SEC. 5. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND MOBILITY MANAGEMENT. The Federal Transit Administration will provide technical assistance to nonprofit organizations that offer transportation services to older individuals in urbanized areas through a cooperative agreement with the National Center on Senior Transportation. The Federal Transit Administration will make grants to human services organizations to disseminate best practices and provide grants for innovative approaches to address the mobility needs of older individuals. Authorization of appropriations includes $5,500,000 for fiscal year 2012 and $6,000,000 for fiscal year 2013. The Federal Transit Administration will make grants to nonprofit aging services organizations to offer mobility management services and develop enhanced technology. Authorization of appropriations includes $3,000,000 for fiscal year 2012 and $5,000,000 for fiscal year 2013.
